Author: GrammarAmerican

Comment: Sex based leagues are intended as competitive levels.  Women have played on ncaa men’s teams in football, basketball, swimming, and baseball. This is because those individual athletes were and are most competitive as women participating in the men’s leagues.  Girls regularly play on boys teams at the high school and younger levels. Primarily in football and wrestling.  Roughly between 100-200 girl athletes in each US state play on boys teams. This is because these girls were and are most competitive as girls participating in the boys leagues.  Women and young adults after a sex change are no longer competitive in the women’s and high school girl’s leagues, men and young adults after a sex change are no longer competitive in men’s and high school boy’s leagues. All athletes are placed in the leagues that are most competitive for them.   It is up to the governing bodies of a sport, the leagues, the schools and organizations, the teams, the coaches, and the athletes to determine where athletes need to participate in order to compete.

Comment: I'm not sure how any of that follows what I said.  The issue for the right isn't women not being able to participate, it's that trans-women occasionally compete on the same teams as biological women.  Nobody's rights are being violated in "woke" schools.  Denying trans people the right to be trans is absolutely violating their civil rights.    When I say sports don't matter, what I mean is that it doesn't matter if once in a blue moon a trans woman has an "unfair" advantage being on a women's team, because who wins or loses a sports game has absolutely no impact on real life (especially in high school).  Besides, there are biological women who have just as much an "advantage" as a trans woman due to their own genetics making them taller or stronger than most women the boxer from the last Olympics that everyone on the right was sure was trans is a clear example of this).  Should they be banned from women's sports as well?  I thought the right was against the idea of "participation trophies".  If anything, having a tougher opponent should be encouraged because it will make the kids train harder to compete and will teach them that life isn't always fair.  Isn't that something the right loves to say anyway?
